Award.AwardTitle: EAR-PF: An Investigation of Continental Rift-Parallel Deformation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. D. Sarah Stamps has been awarded an NSF Earth Science Postdoctoral Fellowship to conduct research and develop a GPS geodesy education program while at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. This project aims to confirm and elucidate the origin of the dynamic processes driving rift-parallel surface deformation observed along the East African Rift, an archetype continental rift system. Dr. Stamps will (1) occupy geodetic benchmarks with Global Positioning System (GPS) instruments at previously measured sites along the Western Branch and Rukwa Rift where rift-parallel deformation is indicated, and (2) test candidate mechanisms for rift-parallel deformation using an adaptive finite element technique that can solve viscoelastic and time-dependent problems at various spatial scales. Verifying the existence of rift-parallel deformation along the East African Rift and determining the responsible mechanism(s) will provide a more complete understanding of rifting processes.

The use of GPS as a tool for monitoring active deformation is vital for advancing knowledge of seismic and volcanic hazards. This project supports the development of a GPS geodesy training program aimed at educating university students to observe millimeter precision surface motions with GPS. The pilot program will be implemented at the University of Antananarivo, Madagascar and documented for future GPS geodesy capacity building efforts in developing countries and within the US.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Along the East African Rift System (EARS), a region where the Earth’s rigid outer shell (lithosphere) is actively extending, a peculiar pattern of surface motions was detected using high precision Global Positioning System (GPS) measurements. Along the EARS where the continent extends East-West the GPS measurements show an approximately North-South motion. Similar “rift-parallel” motions may be characteristic of other active continental rifts along the EARS. Observations in the sub-surface from seismology, SKS-splitting, suggest mantle flow directions correlate with the enigmatic GPS observations. One of the outstanding challenges in the geosciences, and particularly geodynamics, is elucidating the degree which convecting mantle drives surface motions.

In this project the research comprises three major goals: (1) use high precision Global Positioning System instruments to measure surface motions along the Western branch of the EARS (Uganda and Tanzania) to determine if the anomalous rift-parallel surface motions are a system-wide phenomenon, (2) quantify surface motions and associated strain rates for regions of the EARS where rift-parallel deformation is detected, and (3) test the potential role of mantle flow as a mechanism for continental rift-parallel deformation using modern numerical methods.

Our new GPS observations along the Western branch provide evidence that rift-parallel surface motions are systematic in the northern regions of the EARS. We use these new data and existing GPS measurements to derive a new GPS velocity field for the EARS (Figure 1A) and quantify strain rates (Figure 1B). We resolve localized zones of compression and transtension within individual rifts that are corroborated by independent seismic and geologic observations. We also assess the role of mantle flow on surface motions in the Western branch where the mantle is isolated from broad upper mantle thermal anomalies related to plumes. We employ the finite element open-source code ASPECT (Advanced Solver for Problems in Earth’s Convection) to solve for deformation of the mantle-lithosphere system and test the role of horizontal mantle flow on surface motions that are acting at the based of the lithosphere in 3D. Our upper mantle flow calculations reveal an upwelling flow pattern west of the central Western branch that directs northward, along-rift flow in the northern Western branch and southward rift-parallel flow along the southern Western branch similar to the pattern of surface motions detected with GPS (Figure 2). However, the forces generated by the interaction of mantle flow and lithosphere appears insufficient to drive the rift-parallel surface motions. This suggests two possibilities for the dynamics of rift-parallel continental deformation: (1) our current understanding of the physics of lithospheric structure and deformation need revising or (2) shallower, crustal processes such as from lower crustal flow or magmatic processes drive rift-parallel surface motions during continental rifting.

Broader Impacts: To advance the capabilities of the next generation of geoscientists this project involved testing a pilot instructional course in introductory GPS geodesy with a focus on learning precision measurement strategies. The PI worked with the UNAVCO Education and Community Engagement program to create a high quality one-week educational program comprised of lecture and hands-on experience with GPS equipment (http://www.unavco.org/education/advancing-geodetic-skills/short-courses/2014/gps/gps.html). The educational program was implemented at the University of Antananarivo with 20 participants.
